case_vignette:
A 70-year-old man presents with 1 year of a non-healing growth on the right cheek. He says he first noticed it when he accidentally bumped into it and it bled easily. He denies any preceding trauma to the lesion. The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He is a nonsmoker and has never used tobacco products. He has a 30 pack-year history of asbestos exposure. He has a family history of lung cancer and colon cancer. The patient's vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the lesion is a 2 cm, firm, non-tender, and non-ulcerated growth on the right cheek. The patient's skin is otherwise normal. The patient is referred to a dermatologist for further evaluation and biopsy.

Here is the text with the gender-specific references removed:
A 70-year-old person presents with 1 year of a non-healing growth on the right cheek. They say they first noticed it when they accidentally bumped into it and it bled easily. They deny any preceding trauma to the lesion. The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. They are a nonsmoker and have never used tobacco products. They have a 30 pack-year history of asbestos exposure. They have a family history of lung cancer and colon cancer. The patient's vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the lesion is a 2 cm, firm, non-tender, and non-ulcerated growth on the right cheek. The patient's skin is otherwise normal. The patient is referred to a dermatologist for further evaluation and biopsy.

question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a non-healing growth on my right cheek that I've had for about a year.
Has the growth changed in size, color, or texture since you first noticed it?
No, the growth has not changed in size, color, or texture since I first noticed it.
Have you had similar skin issues in the past or any other significant medical history?
I have not had similar skin issues in the past, but I do have a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia.
Have you noticed any bleeding or ulceration in the area of the growth?
Yes, the growth bled easily when I accidentally bumped into it.
Do you have a family history of skin cancer or any other type of cancer?
I have a family history of lung cancer and colon cancer.
Have you experienced any unexplained weight loss, fatigue, or other systemic symptoms recently?
No, I have not experienced any unexplained weight loss, fatigue, or other systemic symptoms recently.
Final Diagnosis: Basal Cell Carcinoma.
